qas.question: Who is interested in the degrees of phonemic length?
What are the phonemic length's three degrees?
What is a matter of dispute among linguists regarding the distinction?
Who isn't interested in the degrees of phonemic length?
What is not a distinctive feature?
Underlong is a degree of what length?
What are the three degrees of phonemic width?

context: One distinctive feature that has caused a great amount of interest among <a0_0><b3_0>linguists<b3_0/><a0_0/> is what is traditionally seen as three <b4_0>degrees of <b5_0>phonemic<b5_0/> length<b4_0/>: <a1_0><b6_0>short, long, and "overlong"<b6_0/><a1_0/>, such that /sɑdɑ/, /sɑˑdɑ/ and /sɑːdɑ/ are distinct. In actuality, the distinction is not purely in the phonemic length, and <a2_0>the underlying phonological mechanism<a2_0/> is still disputed.[citation needed]
